Award.AwardTitle: RET in Engineering and Computer Science Site: UC Berkeley's Context-Based Research Experience for Community College Faculty

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for a three year standard award to support a Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) in Engineering and Computer Science Site program at the University of California-Berkeley, entitled, "RET in Engineering and Computer Science Site: UC Berkeley's Context-Based Research Experience for Community College Faculty", under the direction of Dr. Eli Yablonovitch and Dr. Sharnnia Artis.

This RET Site builds on the intersection of science, engineering, technology, and education and will support a total of 30 STEM faculty members (10 per year) from local California community colleges in the San Francisco Bay Area to undertake independent research at a variety of engineering-related research laboratories associated with the University of California, Berkeley, and to transform the research concepts into curriculum that is linked to technology applications with societal benefits and employment potential. Informed by RET best practices, each summer, the community college faculty members will participate in a 9-week experience. This experience will include an 8-week independent research project in an engineering group in which faculty, postdoctoral researchers, and graduate students are active, available, and involved; and a 1-week team-based curriculum development experience, in which both experiences are placed in the context of a technology application that community college students find exciting, engaging and viable for a future career. During the next academic year, immediately following the faculty's summer experience, follow-up will include webinars, implementing their course module, demonstrating their course module at the RET Site's Context-Based Curriculum Development Workshop, and publishing the curriculum online.

The RET Site programmatic effort will foster community college teachers' understanding of the process of research by engaging in authentic, in-depth, engineering-related research experiences in innovative and cutting-edge topics, such as alternative energy, cyber security and industrial internet, green and sustainability manufacturing, and wearable medical devices. As a result, teachers may in turn engage their community college students in technology-driven education activities through context-based curriculum developed during the research experience. The RET Site will also contribute to research in science and engineering education by providing data on how research experiences influence teachers and their teaching in community college classrooms.

The teacher participants will return to their home community colleges with new skills and tools to teach new scientific and engineering principles in technology contexts that students can relate to and hopefully, will aspire to participate in. Thus, the broader impact of this Context-Based RET Site lies in the potential of increasing engagement and persistence and thus, eventually the retention rate, among community college students majoring in STEM, particularly among entry-level community college students. Given the demographics of community colleges, the RET Site should also contribute to increasing the understanding of math, science and engineering concepts, skills and careers among women and underrepresented minority students. Additionally, this program, especially with its post-program Context-Based Curriculum Development Workshop, will further cultivate and sustain a vibrant network of community college teachers, faculty, postdoctoral, and graduate student researchers with the potential of long-term collaborative partnerships.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Research Experience for Teachers (RET) Site on Context-Based Research Experience for Community College Faculty at the University of California, Berkeley, enabled STEM faculty participants from local California community colleges in the San Francisco Bay Area a unique research and curriculum development experience at the intersection of science, engineering, technology, and education. The underlying concept of this context-based RET program was for faculty participants to conduct cutting-edge research, and then to transform this research experience into new curriculum, tightly linked to technology applications with societal benefits and employment potential.

Each summer, community college faculty members participated in a nine-week RET program, including an eight-week independent research project and a one-week team-based curriculum development experience. During the research part, each RET participant was paired with two mentors: a faculty member and a graduate student or postdoc. The mentors guided the RET participants in independent research activities, at group/laboratory meetings, and through one-on-one mentoring meetings. In addition to conducting independent research, all participants were trained on research protocol, laboratory safety, and scientific ethics. They also participate in academic and professional development activities with special focus on context-based curriculum development. The eight-week independent research project was followed by a one-week curriculum development focus in which outcomes from the research experiences were placed in the context of technology applications, which community college students would find exciting, engaging and viable for a future career. The newly developed courses and course modules were then implemented in the Fall or Spring semesters following the faculty’s summer experience.

 

Intellectual Merit: The goal of this RET was to increase scientific and engineering knowledge and skills of California community college faculty by promoting classroom teaching of leading-edge science and engineering concepts in the context of real-life applications. Closely aligned with project-based learning and inquiry-based science education, the context-based approach is a pedagogical method that brings scientific concepts alive in the community college classroom by tying the teaching with applications that resonate with students. Through this RET program, faculty participants were able to integrate state-of-the-art research findings in alternative energy, cyber security and industrial internet, green and sustainability manufacturing, and wearable medical devices into new community college curriculum. This approach created links between classroom teaching and real-world applications with the goal to introduce community college students into the exciting world of STEM research and technology.

This RET program hosted 27 participants from community colleges in the San Francisco Bay Area. Each participant worked independently on research projects supervised by a faculty member and graduate student or postdoc mentor. Collectively, the 27 RET participants have been advised by 16 faculty mentors and 22 graduate student or postdoc mentors. Importantly, many of the faculty mentors have returned each year because they enjoy hosting the community college faculty participants.

 

Broader Impacts: Providing community college teachers with cutting-edge research experiences to create new curriculum has a broad impact on the development of students and prepares them for further academic studies or entering the workforce. This program thus helped to better educate the next generation of leaders in a wide range of STEM disciplines. After completing the nine-week program, RET participants returned to their home community colleges with new skills and tools to teach scientific and engineering principles in technology contexts. This context-based RET Site thus increased engagement and persistence, and, eventually, the retention rate among community college students majoring in STEM. Given the demographics of community colleges, the RET Site significantly contributed to expanding the understanding of math, science and engineering concepts, skills and careers among women and underrepresented minority students.

 

Comprehensive Evaluation: The RET Site program was annually evaluated by an external evaluator. Community college faculty participants and their mentors were surveyed before, during, and after their participation. In addition, every year, faculty participants took part in an exit interview. All measures (self-reported and observed) indicated highly positive and formative experiences for both the RET participants and their mentors.

 

Publications and Presentations: The RET Site has significantly contributed to research in science and engineering education by providing data on how research experiences influence faculty teachers and their teaching in community college classroom. Key results have been presented at the 2018 American Society for Engineering Education Annual Conference & Exposition by program manager Lea Marlor and external evaluator Catherine Amelink (“The Development of a Context-based Summer Research Program for Community College Faculty in Science and Engineering,” Proceedings of the 2018 American Society for Engineering Education Annual Conference & Exposition, Salt Lake City, UT, Jun 2018).

In addition, results of this context-based RET program have been disseminated through the implementation of new curriculum, developed by the RET participants, at their respective community college home institutions.
